text:
Madison Avenue, east side, from 23rd to 24th Streets. In the centre is the Metropolitan Life Insurance Building, whose expansion will devour the brownstone church on the left. This is the Madison Square Presbyterian Church (1854-1906) from whose pulpit Dr. Charles Parkhurst waged unceasing war on Tammany Hall until that organization was temporarily, at least, overthrown, and its leader, Richard Croker, driven into exile.

1894.

J. S. Johnston, from Brown Brothers.

Metropolitan Building
P.L. Sperr collection
Rec'd January 13, 1945

Madison Square, looking north across the park from the buildings on 23rd Street just east of Broadway. On Madison Avenue, S.E. corner of 25th Street, the Madison will be demolished between 1910 and 1916 to make room for a 20 story office building. On the N.E. corner of 25th Street is the brand new marble building housing the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, on the S.E. corner of 26th Street the former Lawrence Jerome residence, housing the Manhattan Club. With a little remodelling the buildings in this block will be unchanged in 1935. On the N.W. corner the Madison Square Garden, about ten years old, will be demolished in 1925 to make room for the New York Life building. Most of the buildings along 26th Street on the north side of the Square will give way to office buildings between 1910 and 1916; the Hotel Brunswick on the N.E. corner of Fifth Avenue and 27th Street will go down before 1910. The small new white A.S.P.C.A. building on the N.W. corner of Madison and 26th Street will be standing in 1935. To the left, on Fifth Avenue, may be seen part of the Dewey triumphal arch. A mile to the north, seen across the flat roofs in the center background, is the new Manhattan Hotel on the N.W. corner of Madison Avenue and 42nd Street. Winter 1899-1900.

Brown Brothers, Photographers.

General View:
Fifth Avenue from West 23rd Street, giving a wide view of Madison Square, 5th and Madison Avenues looking north.

Charles L. Ritzman.

1900.

Madison Avenue, east side (buildings thereupon), from E. 23rd to 24th Streets as viewed across a corner of Madison Square, from Fifth Avenue. The two office buildings shown are units of the Metropolitan Insurance Co; the larger being the home office prior to tower addition. This feature was constructed on the corner site where the spired Madison Square Presbyterian Church (1854-1906) stands. The domed structure on the opposite corner (N.E. of 24th Street) is being constructed for this congregation and in 1928 will give way for additional offices for the Metropolitan Insurance Co.

December 1905.

Geo. L. Balgue

Madison Avenue, north from East 23rd Street, showing Madison Square Park and its surrounding structures at two different stages. The original Madison Square Garden at 26th Street is being replaced by the New York Life Insurance Company Building. Note the distinctive Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church (N. E. corner of 24th Street) and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (N. E. corner of 25th Street).

Views 1,2: 1908
Views 3,4: September 1928

(1) Madison Avenue, East side between E.23rd Street and E.24th the Metropolitan Life Insurance Building under construction. It is 658 feet high and 103 feet higher than the Washington monument.

Al-Vista and Film Co.

B8 - NEG #3635
B9 - NEG #3636

Madison Avenue, east side, from E. 23rd (right) to 24th Streets, showing the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. tower under construction at the S. E. corner of the latter point. Upon this site formerly stood the old (1854) Madison Square Presbyterian Church. In the deal for this property the Insurance Co. undertook the replacement of same. That appears at the lower left location. Subsequently (about 1928) this will be replaced by an office building. This in turn (after 1940) will be razed and the site form a corner of a block square structure. Views 1 and 2 bear no date; No. 3 being photographed October 10, 1908. Note in the earlier photos the Taft and Sherman banner suspended over E. 23rd Street. In the background is the East River and its Greenpoint shore.

1908

Gift of Urbrock Collection

C1- NEG #3637
C2- NEG #3638
C3- NEG #3639

Madison Avenue, east side, from East 23rd (right) to 24th Street, showing the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company building and tower and the Madison Square Presbyterian Church. The latter, erected in 1906, was formerly on the corner site where the tower is rising. Expansion of the Insurance Company will eventually cause this to be demolished for an office structure and which in turn will be removed for a latter annex that will include the entire 24th to 25th Street block.

View 1: 1908
View 2: October 1914

George L. Balgue

Madison Avenue, east side, between E. 23rd and E. 24th Streets, showing
Metropolitan Life Insurance Building after dark.

Photographer Unknown
about 1908

Madison Avenue, east side, from East 23rd (right) to 24th Streets, showing the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. tower under construction. This, completed occupation of this entire block. Eventually the block north will be similarly included.

The photographer is viewing north eastward towards a background of midtown-eastside tenements and the East River. Close observation will show the J. J. Little & Ives printing plant and units of Bellevue Hospital at the latter point. At the right is 4th Avenue and the Packard Commercial School at the N. E. corner. To the left appears the new and distinctive structure recently erected by the Insurance Co. for the Madison Square Presbyterian Church. Stanford White was the architect.

View 1: 1909
View 2: February 1, 1909
View 3: April 18, 1909

Gift of Ubrock Collection

A general view, south from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Building, (Madison Ave., and 23rd St.), showing in the centre, Union Square Park and in the background, at the left, is the East River, with the Manhattan (first) and Brooklyn (second) Bridges.

About 1909.

Wurts Brothers.
title: General view - [Manhattan - 23rd Street - Madison Avenue (South).]

text:
Madison Avenue, north from 23rd Street, showing the east side of Madison Square, and four buildings on 26th Street. The smallest of these, the third from the corner, is the last of the old brownstone houses which used to fill that block, and will be rebuilt before long. The four-story building on the corner (A.S.P.C.A.) was built shortly prior to 1900.
On the N.E. corner of 24th Street is the latest of the Metropolitan Life Insurance buildings (1920), which replaced the Madison Square Presbyterian Church (built 1906). On the N.E. corner of 25th Street may be seen the Corinthian columns of the New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division, erected about 1898. Madison Square Garden (1890-1925) stands in the block from 26th to 27th Streets. About 1922.

International News Photos, Inc.

Madison Avenue, south from East 26th to 23rd Streets. At the right is Madison Square, the park that identified this thoroughfare. The Manhattan Club is the ornate structure to the left and adjoins the Madison Square Apartments (street canopy). On the right margin appears a portion of the Fuller (Flatiron) Building. The low Hotel Bartholdi is on the left of the latter.

May 18, 1924

Standard Photographic Service
Gift of Borough President of Manhattan

Madison Avenue, east side, from 26th to 23rd Streets along Madison Square seen from the west. On N.E. corner of 26th Street stands the New York Life Building, on the site of the second Madison Square Garden. On S.E. corner of 26th Street the Manhattan Club (old Jerome residence) has been remodelled, balconies removed. At the right is a good view of the Metropolitan tower at 24th Street. This view remains substantially the same in 1935. 1926.

photograph by Browning Studios.

Madison Ave., at the N.E. corner of East 26th Street (the New York Life Insurance Co. Building) as seen across Madison Square Park from the west side of Fifth Ave. at 25th Street.

July 14, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same structure viewed across the south westerly corner of the Park (Fifth Avenue and 23rd Street) from a vantage point at the base of the Flatiron Building.

Note the silhouetted statue of the Hon. Samuel J. Tilden in the foreground.

August 5, 1938

George D. Chinn

Madison Ave., at the N.E. corner of East 26th Street (the New York Life Insurance Co. Building) as seen across Madison Square Park from the west side of Fifth Ave. at 25th Street.

August 5, 1938

George D. Chinn

Madison Avenue, from East 23rd (right) to 26th (left) Street, (buildings thereupon) as photographed across Madison Square Park from 5th Avenue. Prominently shown is the progressive blockwide project conducted by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. This annex will on completion include the entire site from 24th to 25th Streets, and east to 4th Avenue. The remaining structure (N. E. corner of 24th Street), is the office building that replaced the distinguished Madison Square Presbyterian Church. Completed and occupied is the easterly half that fronts on 4th Avenue.

July 18, 1939
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr

Metropolitan Life Insurance Building, situated on Madison Avenue, at the northeast corner of 23rd Street and Madison Avenue, with the main entrance on Madison Avenue. The architects were Napoleon LeBrun and Sons, and the builder Jer. T. Smith.

No Record of Photography
